body: +1 This is kinda needed for DST support.

Strictly speaking, both structures need a `#[repr(C)]` for a transmute between them to be defined. (Also, all copies of the `Rc` need to be upgraded to `Arc` or else the use of non-atomic instructions in some of the `Rc`s is UB.)

@huonw I'm not just transmuting blindly. In my library I check that it's the last Rc before upgrading to an Arc. Actually, I'll probably just Arc everything for convenience. This is still needed for DST though!
Could you be sure to add a test for this as well? I'm not sure I'd personally be in favor of a strategy such as this, but this should have tests no matter what.

Do we really want these to be `#[repr(C)]`? `Rc` and `Arc` could support `unsafe` deconstruction and construction methods like `Vec` instead to accomplish the same thing and LLVM could likely optimize the translation to a no-op if they have the same representation.

I'm **strongly** against marking these as `#[repr(C)]`. It is counter to the goals that led to making the representation implementation defined in the first place. Due to these being generic types, there is no way to choose the optimal representation by hand.
If transmuting between them is desired, they should use the same inner data structure. There's no reason to make the sacrifice of it being `#[repr(C)]`.

Since `Cell` is simply a newtype wrapper, it could be marked `#[repr(C)]` with little to no change, and that would allow transmute between `Cell<uint>` and `AtomicUint`. I haven't tried to write code, but I think that would allow a no-op translation between `RcBox` and `ArcBox`, or something along those lines.

Marking a newtype as `#[repr(C)]` is not a no-op. It doesn't make sense to have implementation defined representations if it's going to be subverted like this for prominent core types. It defeats both the hardening / fuzzing side of things via random order / padding and reordering fields to minimize the size.

Remember that he `T` has to come last for DST, and reordering the strong and weak counts won't do anything to minimize size. There is a fuzzing argument to be made, though, so I'll see what i can do about making Rc and Arc share the same Box type.

> Remember that he `T` has to come last for DST, and reordering the strong and weak counts won't do anything to minimize size. 

The order is implementation defined for each instantiation. It choose a different order based on alignment  / size and whether a type is dynamically sized. That's the entire point of it being implementation defined.
The compiler cannot tell if a `Rc<T>` will be used as a `Rc<Trait>` or not statically, so the unsized field always has to be in a known place.
@huonw I think what @thestinger means is that an `Rc<Trait>` may have a different field order than `Rc<uint>` which may be different than `Rc<BigStruct>`.

It wouldn't be very useful from a performance perspective if it could not tackle generic types sanely. The biggest argument for having an implementation defined representation is the fact that it's not possible for the programmer to choose optimal representations in generic types. The non-generic cases could be dealt with via a lint without making the representation implementation defined.

@reem, I understood, and that's what I'm saying is impossible. An `Rc<uint>` needs to be coercible to `Rc<Trait>` for any (object-safe) `Trait` that `uint` implements so the representations need to be compatible, i.e. unsized field last (since the fields need to be at the same fixed offsets from each other for all types).
Having implementation defined representations is very questionable if dynamically sized types are going to freeze many representations in unideal / deterministic states.
I don't see how the compiler can be smart enough to take this into account, while still having the freedom to perform these optimizations in general...

The `#[repr(C)]` usage has been removed, and the other comments have been addressed. The patch got bigger, but now `Rc` and `Arc` share a common representation.

r again?

These transmutes are still unsafe since Arc and Rc are still not guaranteed
to have the same layout. However, now the solution is very simple: instead
of transmuting just create an instance of the other type from the input,
i.e. `Arc { _ptr: self._ptr }`.
On Mon, Dec 1, 2014 at 5:59 PM Clark Gaebel notifications@github.com
wrote:

> The #[repr(C)] usage has been removed, and the other comments have been
> addressed.
> 
> r again?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/19347#issuecomment-65151539.
@reem `_ptr` isn't `pub`.
@cgaebel Expose new `unsafe` "raw" constructors, which take an `*mut RcBox<T>`, like in `Vec`.

I don't like the idea of unsafe constructors where the only valid thing to pass to them is a pointer to something that is only possible to construct from inside liballoc itself. It doesn't make sense to expose that to the end user.

Assuming a not-insane compiler, I don't see why the layout of `A { x: *mut X }` and `B { y: *mut Y }` would be any different.

> Assuming a not-insane compiler, I don't see why the layout of A { x: *mut X } and B { y: *mut Y } would be any different.

Those aren't guaranteed to have the same representation. The reasons why have already been discussed in depth elsewhere and have been mentioned here.
How? Random order / Random padding shouldn't affect this type of usage.

In this case it's actually `A { x: *mut X }` and `B { x: *mut X }`.

Unlikely to be different doesn't mean guaranteed to be exactly the same, which is what you need to justify `transmute`.

@cgaebel: The `struct` representation is entirely implementation defined. The compiler is allowed to insert padding before or after the first and only field. The status quo is that you don't get to make any assumptions about the representation.
Fine. Added the new function and dropped the transmute.
Done. Everyone good?

@cgaebel this seems like a pretty niche use case which is not likely to survive stabilization and could potentially be some baggage we have to carry for awhile. Do you have any benchmarks, numbers, or other rationale for this change beyond it's occasionally nice to perform?

@alexcrichton the ability to non-atomically refcount in one thread, send to another thread, then continue non-atomically refcounting is useful. I will be using a similar scheme with html5ever to refcount Iobufs, and figured it makes sense to pull the strategy into the standard library.

This seems to be in direct conflict with 'struct representation is undefined.' On one hand, I can see changing this, because why not, but on the other hand, this pull adds tests that directly contradict a language semantic.
@steveklabnik: It was changed to reusing the same inner type so it should be fine now.

I think that in terms of stabilizing the interface of `Rc` and `Arc` that this is not something that we're going to be willing to commit to. The fact that the two structures are laid out currently is an implementation detail which isn't necessarily something that we want to guarantee until the end of time into the future. Your specific use case of sending a unique `Rc` seems orthogonal to converting to and from `Arc`/`Rc` as the `is_unique` method could also be used for that purpose.

For now I'm going to close this PR on the grounds that stabilizing an interface such as this is an incredibly large commitment I don't think we're ready to make. If we get a large amount of demand for a feature such as this, however, we can certainly reconsider adding this in a backwards-compatible fashion.

@alexcrichton Right now it is actually impossible to send a unique `Rc` of any kind, since `Rc` doesn't provide any sort of conditional `into_inner` - even if it did, using it in this manner would require copying the value onto the stack, deallocating the `Rc` allocation, sending the value, then allocating a totally new `Rc` on the other task. 

It gets worse, because "copy the value onto the stack" is actually impossible for unsized types, which both `Rc` and `Arc` are supposed to support in the future.

That... seems like why `Arc` exists? Have you profiled your application and the hottest spot is atomic refcounts to show that the atomicity is too much to bear?

As an example of something that could go wrong with a transformation such as this, we're blocked in the future to ever performing any form of thread-local optimization for a `Rc` instance by being required to support cheaply sending a unique `Rc` across threads.
Thread local optimizations for Rc? That sounds cool! Like what?

We've always had some concept of thread local heaps, even if most of the
time it's theoretical.
@thestinger should know what using jemalloc as a thread-local allocator
would entail and how significant the performance benefits might be.

I don't think there's anything to gain with jemalloc. It already has thread local caches and would still need to fill / flush from the central arenas if it knew the data wasn't sent across threads. The size of the caches needs to be heavily constrained to prevent pathological memory usage from very common allocation patterns across threads.
It is _much_ easier to write a thread-local custom allocator than a global allocator with thread caches though.
What's wrong with merging this as `experimental` and dropping support (or stabilizing it) when the thread-local optimization meat is finalized?
